data.text: Contents
Introduction

All Mid and South Essex Hospitals welcome assistance dogs including Guide Dogs to its premises. It is appreciated that these dogs are essential for the mobility, wellbeing of patients and carers or visitors to the trust. The Mid and South Essex Trust appreciates that these dogs have undergone a rigorous training program and also welcomes those dogs that are undergoing this training. With an increasing number of assistance dogs, this policy relates to those dogs trained in accordance with the standards set by Assistance Dogs UK. It also includes animal assisted intervention which includes Animal Assisted Activity (AAA) and Animal Assisted Therapy (AAT). AAA and AAT dogs are accompanied by a handler and usually form part of a patients care plan.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to ensure the trust is meeting the requirements as set out in the Equality Act and making reasonable adjustments for patients with a disability.
The Equality Act 2010

2.2.1  The Equality Act 2010 legally protects people from discrimination in the workplace and in wider society. It replaced previous anti-discrimination acts with a single act. Making the law easier to understand and strengthens protection in some circumstances. The definition of disability under The Equality Act 2010 states that a person is disabled if they have a physical or mental impairment that has a long term and substantial negative effect on a person's ability to do normal activities. It is for this reason that it is a legal requirement that assistance dogs are allowed into the premises except in exceptional circumstances.
To keep our visitors and staff safe, protect our vulnerable patients and limit the spread of COVID-19, we continue to restrict the number of people allowed on to our hospital sites.
Definitions

table_items.text: In general, an assistance dog is trained to aid or assist an individual with a disability. Many are trained by an assistance dog organisation, or by their handler, often with the help of a professional trainer.
Any person who comes to visit a patient and is not there in a professional capacity.
Arrangements made with an individual visitor and the Nurse in charge of the ward to facilitate visiting outside normal visiting hours due to an extraordinary set of circumstances.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
The Chief Executive and wider Trust Board have key roles and are responsible for:
Ensuring that the Trust meets requirements set out by statutory and regulatory authorities such as the Department of Health, Commissioners and the Care Quality Commission;
Ensuring that processes are in place so that: clinical staff are aware of this policy and adhere to its requirements of appropriate resources exist to meet the requirements of this policy.

The Executive Directors are responsible for ensuring that all operational managers in their area are aware of this policy, understand its requirements and support its implementation with relevant staff.
The Associate Medical Director and Consultants are responsible for ensuring procedures are understood and carried out by medical staff involved in the implementation of this policy

Senior Matrons/ Matrons/ Site Co-ordinators are responsible for providing support in dealing with difficult / complex circumstances / situations for Ward/Department Managers or the Nurse in Charge during out of office hours.
Ward/Unit Matrons and Managers are responsible for:
Ensuring that staff carry out the duties prescribed in this policy;
Ensuring that patients and relatives are aware of the policy;
Making judgement for exclusions to this policy.
Ward Staff are responsible for ensuring Patients and Visitors are informed of the Trust policy
Communications Team is responsible for ensuring this policy is communicated within the Trust and to external stakeholders
Guidelines

Under the Equality Act 2010 it is unlawful to refuse entry for an assistance dog except in exceptional circumstances. Assistance dogs are generally trained by charities, although can be owner trained. It is therefore essential that staff are aware and able to check that the assistance dog is bona fide and trained to the standards of Assistance Dogs UK, dogs will:
Not wander freely, instead staying with its owner sitting at its feet
Not display any reactive or aggressive behaviour such as snarling or growling
Go to toilet on command
Either wear a harness, or a dog jacket which will usually indicate the organisation or charity whose training program it is undertaking.
Will always wear a collar with a disc with its number.
The dog owner may also be carrying its Passport, displaying a picture of the dog and owner.
(Refer to appendix 3 for a guide to the assistance dogs)
The Trusts responsibility

The ward or clinic manager or clerk will ensure that assistance dogs are allowed to the area unless there are exceptional and extreme circumstances. All reasonable adjustments will be undertaken. If there is no clear way forward to allow the dog access to the premises, a clear explanation will be provided to the owner. If a suitable suggestion is made, this will be considered and a decision made.

If access is not allowed, the Trust will accept that additional support will/may need to be provided. This may include constant supervision especially where the assistance dog detects medical issues. The trust accepts that shortage of staff to provide such assistance is not acceptable.
After the visit, the ward manager, clerk may decide that it would be appropriate to contact the Domestic Cleaning staff to clean the area visited.
Any staff that come into contact with the dogs should ensure they sanitise their hands thoroughly before and after.

In exceptional circumstances e.g. if a critical patient arrives in the emergency department, the reception staff will supervise the assistance dog. They will need to call the patients next of kin, or the relevant charity helpline for immediate assistance to take responsibility for the dog. The trust will flag their records to indicate that they require the support from an assistance dog.
The assistance dog owner's responsibility

The assistance dog owner accepts that staff are not responsible for their dogs. The staff will not assist them with exercising, feeding or toileting the animal. The owner will not allow their dog to be unleashed and therefore move freely in the premises. The dog will be fully vaccinated and up to date with all its treatments.
The owner will report to the ward or clinic upon arrival and take instruction from the staff in relation to possible adjustments that may have been made.
The dogs will not go on the beds or sofas.

Assistance dogs will not be able to remain in the ward overnight unless they are able to adequately care for the dog on their own. Where an overnight or day stay visit is required alternative boarding arrangements are strongly recommended as staff will not be able to assist with care for their dogs.
Infection control

All assistance dogs are fully vaccinated and up to date with all relevant treatments such as flea and worming etc. Whilst this is accepted and understood, it would be inappropriate for dogs to be allowed in certain areas. It has been agreed that this will include theatres, recovery post op wards and areas of food preparation. In all other areas it may be necessary for reasonable adjustments to be made. These may include:
Booking the last appointment for a clinic visit to allow the room to be cleaned, as would usually happen at the end of the day
Allowing the visit to the ward as usual. However if there is a risk of infection, such as a respiratory or wound management ward, allowing an alternative room to be used.
If the owner of the assistance dog is the patient, where possible consider a side room or an alternative area away from a bay for the assisted dog to visit
If there are other patients who are allergic or who have a fear of dogs, again allow an alternative area for the owner to meet the assistance dog.
Training requirements
More information can be found on this website https://www.ecl.org/ . Please see appendix 2 for a case study example.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Carers Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Carers Steering Group documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Carers Steering Group of the approved documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Appendix 1: Potential scenarios within which reasonable adjustments can be made
SCENARIO ONE

A patient arrives at the X-ray Department. They have an assistance dog wearing a red and white checked harness. They are also accompanied by another person who appears to be assisting them. Dogs are not allowed in the X-ray room so what should you do?

POTENTIAL SOLUTION: A red and white checked harness indicates that the person is both sight and hearing impaired. It is most likely that the person accompanying them is a Communicator Guide. The Communicator Guide will have to go into the X-ray with them, although stand behind the screen once the patient is aware of what is going to happen. Therefore, since the assistance dog cannot wait outside on its own, the dog should accompany the patient into the X-ray room, and before the image is taken, both the Communicator Guide and assistance dog should remain behind the protective screen.
SCENARIO TWO

A patient arrives at  the clinic with an assistance dog wearing a purple jacket. After checking in at reception, they cautiously walk towards a seat. Another patient comes to reception and advises that they are allergic to dogs and is unhappy that the dog is in the clinic. As the patient tries to sit down, they fall to the floor. What should you do?
POTENTIAL SOLUTION: The purple jacket indicates that this is a K9 mobility

dog. They have been trained to assist their owners to pick up things and help them if they fall. Advise the other patient who is unhappy with the dog that they will remain with their owner and not wander freely. If necessary either the patient with the allergy or the patient with the assistance dog should be found an alternative room to wait until the appointment. As the owner has fallen, ask the owner if they would like assistance. The owner may use their assistance dog to get up from the floor. If they need assistance follow usual protocols relating to assisting patients from the floor. Wash your hands.
SCENARIO THREE

A person is walking along the corridor with an assistance dog wearing a white harness. The dog appears to be agitated and when the person sits down, the dog jumps onto the chairs nearby. When another person sits nearby, the dog growls at them. Understandably, the second person is upset and speaks to you. What should do?

POTENTIAL SOLUTION: Irrespective of the colour of the harness, all assistance dogs trained by charities under the umbrella of Assistance Dogs UK would not growl or snarl. Allowing sufficient space between yourself and the person with the dog, ask how they trained their dog and whether they have proof of this training. All registered assistance dog owners will be happy to provide this. If the person is unable to provide evidence, due to the aggressive or agitated nature of the dog, advise the person that they will have to leave unless they can provide such proof. If the person is waiting to attend an appointment then advise them they will have to ask someone to come and collect the dog and a member of staff will assist them, or alternatively they can change their appointment. At the next appointment they should attend without the dog or proof of the training and vaccinations.
SCENARIO FOUR

A person arrives at the Endoscopy Suite with their Assistance Dog. This dog is wearing a red jacket. This indicates it may be a medical alert dog and detect hypoglycaemic attacks before the patient is aware. Usually dogs are not allowed in the Endoscopy Suite. What should you do?

POTENTIAL SOLUTION: Is a spare room available for this patient? If so, use this room for the patient and their assistance dog. If not, allow the dog to enter with the patient but draw the curtain round the bed. This dog should stay with the patient due to the medical detection ability. When it is the patients turn to have their Endoscopy, take the dog to the reception staff to wait whilst the procedure is undertaken. Once the procedure has finished, return the assistance dog to the patient. At any time when the assistance dog is not in the company of the patient, a member of staff MUST remain with the patient at all times.
SCENARIO FIVE

A patient has broken their leg and is on the ward with their leg in traction. The patient has a history of severe mental health issues, and their current situation is exacerbating this health condition. A relative has suggested their companion dog is allowed to visit. What would you recommend?
POTENTIAL SOLUTION: If there is no open wound, and since most dogs used to assist people with mental health issues are small, such as a spaniel or

terrier. Would it be possible to move the patient to a side room whilst the relative brings the dog to visit its owner? If not, allow the dog to visit but draw a curtain round the bed. Provide inco sheets or towels to the patient to cover the bed. This will then allow the patient to cuddle their dog as they are unable to get out of

bed. Once they have left, remove the protective sheets or towels and dispose of them in the usual way. Sanitise your hands and that of the patient. If appropriate, as the domestic cleaning staff to sweep the floor.
SCENARIO SIX
A blind patient needs to stay in hospital overnight. They have asked if their Guide Dog can stay with them. What do you do?

POTENTIAL SOLUTION: If the patient will be unable to care for the dog themselves, they will have to make alternative arrangements for the dog to be cared for. If the owner is able to care for the dog, suggest that the dog is cared for by someone else. Offer to change the appointment for the procedure which requires an overnight stay to an alternative day where someone will be able to care for the assistance dog. If this is not possible, there is no legal reason why the assistance dog cannot remain with its owner. Therefore move the patient to a side room after clarifying that the nursing staff will be unable to assist in any care of the dog. When the patient leaves the following day, as usual, ensure the room is thoroughly cleaned. Ensure all staff wash their hands after entering the room and ask the patient to wash their hands on a regular basis.
